material.mattext: Based on the p-value you can conclude that:
the data provide significant evidence that the proportion of US adults who oppose gay marriage is 50%.
the data provide significant evidence that the majority of US adults oppose gay marriage.
the data does not provide enough evidence to conclude that the majority of US adults oppose gay marriage.
the data provide evidence that Ha is more likely than Ho (i.e., it is more likely that the majority of US adults oppose gay marriage).

Incorrect. This statement says that there is evidence that Ho is true. Recall that this is a conclusion that we can NEVER make. I think it may be helpful for you to read comment 3 (right before this activity) and try again.
Good Job! Indeed, since the p-value is small (less than .05) we have evidence to reject Ho and accept Ha, or in other words, conclude that the majority of US adults oppose gay marriage.
Incorrect. While this statement is a legitimate conclusion, it is not the right conclusion in this case. Since the p-value is small (less than .05) we reject Ho, and accept Ha.

Incorrect. Recall that when the p-value (less than .05) we conclude that the data provide enough evidence to reject Ho and accept Ha. It should be noted that the statement that you chose is actually statistically wrong. Note that the proportion of US adults who oppose gay marriage is a parameter (p), and therefore a fixed, unknown quantity which we are doing inference about. You can talk about the probability that a random variable takes a certain value(s), but not about the probability or likelihood that a fixed quantity takes a certain value(s).
